intro: Eritrichium virgatum, commonly known as the Virginia mouse-ear, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes many other flowering plants with small, cruciform flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, open habitats such as meadows and woodland edges. It has hairy, spoon-shaped leaves and produces clusters of small, white or pale purple flowers. Eritrichium virgatum is often found in shaded areas and is known for its delicate appearance and ecological importance to pollinators.
